awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS: UA-TRIPODS - Building Theoretical Foundations for Data Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
UA-TRIPODS aims to build a transformative and highly interactive data science hub in the Southwestern United States for the integration of research, education, and outreach in the theoretical foundations of data science.  Through research, education, and outreach targeted to high school students through postdoctoral fellows, UA-TRIPODS will help establish and encourage a diverse population to pursue careers in quantitative and computational data science.  The intellectual merits of the project include identifying fundamental areas where progress in the theoretical foundations is imperative, developing mathematical and algorithmic principles of data science, and basic research on topics ranging from the theory of large scale networks and optimization to statistical modeling for natural language processing and Bayesian methods.  This is accomplished by extending long-standing collaborations with experts in the foundational disciplines - theoretical computer science, mathematics, and statistics - and motivated by problems in the domain sciences and industry.  New mathematical, statistical, and algorithmic principles will strengthen the foundations of theoretical data science, while driving discovery and innovation for emerging applications.  UA-TRIPODS will also cultivate new partnerships with local industries engaged in data-centric enterprises in astronomy, environmental science, genomics, lunar and planetary sciences, medicine, transportation, and optical sciences.

Research Working Groups will pursue fundamental questions in a number of different areas in the theoretical foundations of data science.  By ensuring each group includes researchers from each area of the foundational disciplines, while also pairing these groups with science and industry partners, UA-TRIPODS will ensure that these projects will benefit from a truly transdisciplinary collaboration.  Progress in collaboration will be measured by specialized program evaluation metrics.  Yearly workshops, seminars, and brainstorming/visioning activities will enable UA-TRIPODS to lay the foundation for the future of training and research in data science.  In addition, this project will support the development of a new undergraduate degree in Statistics and Data Science at the University of Arizona, expanded online offerings, and facilitation of cooperation in graduate education (both among the foundational disciplines and with the domain sciences).  Students will be provided with opportunities to experience first-hand data analysis and interdisciplinary research and education.  UA-TRIPODS will also engage partnering colleges and universities across the Southwest in the institute activities and then utilize these connections to support novel and effective inter-university and intra-university research and educational programs.  Partnerships with Hispanic Serving Institutions and Tribal Colleges in southern California, Arizona, New Mexico, and western Texas will be strengthened.

por.por_cntn:
The mission of the UA-TRIPODS institute was to build an integrated data science research and education institute on its theoretical foundations. Throughout its project period, the UA-TRIPODS institute successfully created an organic ecosystem to nurture and support deep-level and sustaining transdisciplinary collaborations in theoretical data science among three core communities: Computer Science, Mathematics, and Statistics. Under the ?data to knowledge to action? principle, the UA-TRIPODS attracted data science researchers and practitioners together and built a vibrant and close-bonded community around the institute, connecting their joint efforts through various research, education, and outreach activities. The institute research program was coordinated through research working groups (RWGs), which typically consisted of faculty, postdocs, graduates, and undergraduates and were led jointly by the representation of CS/Math/Stat faculty. The research themes of RWGs were diverse and broad, including  large-scale networks and graphs, data visualization and interpretation, imaging sciences, natural language processing, large-scale optimization, statistical machine learning, Bayesian methods, and spatial and temporal data analysis. The research collaborations led to exciting findings and innovative results, which advanced  theoretical foundations of data science and improved its practice as well. These works were published in top conference proceedings in computer science, workshops with special themes such as NLP and visualization, prestigious journals of mathematics and statistics, as well as journals with high impact in domain sciences such as medicine, geosciences, and engineering. The UA-TRIPODS researchers actively disseminated their findings by giving invited talks, seminars, and short courses at professional conferences, offering introductory lectures and short courses to the general public, and developing new courses. The institute organized weekly "TRIPODS Seminar Series", where more than eighty invited talks were delivered by visitors and collaborators, from both academia and industry, on theory and applications of data science. In addition, the UA-TRIPODS organized the annual ?Southwest Summer Conference on Data Science? at Biosphere 2 to showcase recent advances in data science and inspire new ideas. Travel support was provided for young researchers to encourage their participation and presentation. Each year, the UA-TRIPODS also sponsored the ?Women in Data Science? (WiDS) regional conferences. One major mission of the institute is to enhance the training of next generation data scientists at various levels, from postdocs to graduates to undergraduates and high school students, by exposing them to modern data science problems and challenges from multiple perspectives, and helping them master transdisciplinary collaborations and communication skills. Since its very beginning, the UA-TRIPODS supported four postdocs and 6-10 graduate students each year, who were typically co-advised by the faculty members from different disciplines. Furthermore, the institute played a key role in designing the curricula for the new undergraduate program in statistics and data science at the University of Arizona. The program aims to offer rigorous and comprehensive training in data science, covering both data science foundation courses in mathematics, statistics, and computer science, as well as a broad range of specialized and applications courses in domain sciences. The number of student enrollment was more than doubled in the first three years since the launch of the new major. In addition, the institute strived to involve undergraduates in research groups and projects and supported them via the REU supplement fund, organized special events such as UArizona Machine Learning Literacy Project, helped to organize undergraduate data science competition events ?ASA Datafest? for the three public universities of Arizona, and outreached to local high school students. In summary, UA-TRIPODS was a successful project to prove the feasibility and necessity of building a collaborative and productive entity for data science research, education, and outreach among the three communities: computer science, mathematics, and statistics.
